1.title: Following an aviation accident in the Republic of Serbia, to which of the following must the accident be reported as expeditiously as possible?

variants.a: The Civil Aviation Authority and the local police.
variants.b: The Chief Inspector of the Air Accident Investigation Branch (AAIB) and to the local police.
variants.c: The home airfield of the aircraft involved in the accident.
variants.d: The nearest Air Traffic Control Unit.

2.title: If a pilot judges that his aircraft is in grave and imminent danger, his message should begin with thewords:

variants.a: Mayday Mayday Mayday.
variants.b: Pan Pan Pan Pan Pan Pan.
variants.c: Either Pan Pan Pan Pan Pan Pan or Mayday Mayday Mayday.
variants.d: Emergency Emergency Emergency.

3.title: Which one of the following statements is false? An accident must be reported if, between the time that anyone boards an aircraft to go flying and until everyone has left it:

variants.a: A passenger dies from natural causes.
variants.b: Anyone is killed or seriously injured while in or on the aircraft.
variants.c: The aircraft incurs damage or structural failure.
variants.d: The aircraft is completely inaccessible or missing.

4.title: Which of the following cases constitutes an aircraft accident?

variants.a: The injury of a person on the ground after being struck by any part of an aircraft which had detached from the aircraft while it was airborne but where the safety of the aircraft was not necessarily compromised.
variants.b: A lightning strike on an aircraft in flight.
variants.c: An engine failure in flight.
variants.d: A burst main gear or tailwheel tyre during the take-off or landing roll.

5.title: If a pilot elects to make a distress or urgency call, on which frequency should he first transmit, as an alternative to 121.5 MHz?

variants.a: The frequency he is currently using.
variants.b: He should always change immediately to 121.5 MHz before transmitting.
variants.c: The frequency of the nearest airfield with a full Air traffic Control Service.
variants.d: His home airfield frequency.

6.title: In establishing noise preferential routes, turns during take off and climb should not be required unless the aircraft has reached:

variants.a: 500 ft above terrain or the highest obstacles under the flight path.
variants.b: 1000 ft above terrain or the highest obstacles under the flight path.
variants.c: 1500 ft above terrain or the highest obstacles under the flight path.

variants.a: Urgency phase.
variants.b: Uncertainty phase.

variants.a: Red anti-collision light

variants.a: Right wing tip: green light, left wing tip: red light, tail: white light.

variants.b: Land immediately at the nearest aerodrome.

variants.d: Return to his base airfield and declare the aircraft unserviceable until the light has been repaired.

variants.a: Must be on all the time the engine of an aircraft is running.

variants.a: When using manila ropes tie-down.
variants.b: When using nylon ropes tie-down.

variants.a: Turn into wind and idle at the recommended RPM.
variants.b: Shut off the engine immediately.

23.title: What is the proper pilot procedure in case of a popped-out circuit breaker?

variants.a: Wait until the circuit breaker cools and push it in; if it popes up again, do not Push the circuit breaker and hold it firmly in by finger until land.

variants.a: Break-up of a piston valve.

variants.a: Fuel starvation.

variants.c: Break-up of a piston or valve.

variants.a: Apply sufficient power to keep the engine warm.
variants.b: Turn on carburetor heating.

27.title: What is the reason for shutting down an aviation reciprocating engine using the mixture lever rather than the ignition switch?

variants.a: By doing that we avoid self-ignition due to presence of the fuel/air mixture in cylinders.

variants.c: By doing that we prevent the engine to be shut down at too high temperature.

variants.a: A placard should be placed on the aircraft warning others of "live magnetos".

variants.a: Visual checking the fuel level in the reservoir.

44.title: What fuel should you use in your aircraft if the specified grade is not available?

variants.a: The next higher grade of aviation fuel.

variants.a: Detonations.

variants.d: The manifold pressure with the propeller control, and then reducing the RPM with the throttle.

90.title: When transiting an airplane with a constant-speed propeller from a cruise to a climb, the pilot should :

91.title: Shortly after an aviation engine start-up you noticed on the left-zero ammeter a high current reading despite of all electrical consumers not connected? You should normally :

variants.a: Do nothing, because in such cases an alternator provides the electrical current for battery charging only, which normally deplenishes a little during an engine start-up.
variants.b: Shut down the engine immediately, because the alternator is not functioning.
variants.c: Reset the alternator master switch and, if the condition does not recover, shut down the engine and report to the mechanic non-operating alternator.

92.title: What is the meaning of the zero reading on a left-zero ammeter in flight?

variants.a: Normal condition because none of electrical consumers is switched on.
variants.b: The alternator is not functioning.
variants.c: Deplenishing accumulator.

93.title: How could you recognize by the indication of the left-zero ammeter a non-functioning aircraft alternator?  The instrument reading should be :

variants.a: Zero and stays zero even after the significant electrical consumer is switched on (e.i. The landing light).
variants.b: Maximum.
variants.c: Increase significantly after the electrical consumer is switched on. PPL (A) – Operational proceduresLatest information about the exam can be found atwww.cad.gov.rs/osoblje.php      15 / 25

94.title: Shortly after aircraft engine start-up you notice that the pointer of a center-zero ammeter is deflected to the right with electrical consumers switched off. This indication means :

variants.a: Charging accumulator, because during an engine start-up the accumulator normally deplenishes a little.
variants.b: Deplenishing accumulator, because the alternator is not functioning, therefore alternator exciting should be attempted by switching the master switch on and off. If the pointer does not return to zero, the engine should be shut down and the mechanic advised.
variants.c: Deplenishing accumulator, therefore the engine should be shut down.

95.title: What may zero reading on the center-zero ammeter in flight indicates?

variants.a: Normal condition; the alternator provides electrical power for electrical equipment.
variants.b: Alternator off-line.
variants.c: No electrical equipment is switched on.
variants.d: Abnormal condition; the battery provides electrical power for electrical equipment.

96.title: In flight you notice that the pointer of a center-zero ammeter is deflected to the left. What does this indication mean and what should you as the pilot of an aircraft normally do?

variants.a: Not-normal condition; the accumulator deplenishes, because the alternator is not functioning or is not capable to cover all the demands of electrical consumers connected. If after switching off-on of the master switch the situation does not recover, an electrical consumption should be reduced to minimum and a landing should be made to the nearest suitable airfield.
variants.b: Normal condition; the accumulator is charging, therefore the flight will be continued, the indication of an instrument should be monitored and a drop of indication should be expected.
variants.c: Normal condition; the instruments indicate present consumption of the electricity, provided by the alternator.

97.title: In flight you notice the orange light glowing on the instrumental panel. What does this mean?

variants.a: Alternator does not deliver any electrical current.
variants.b: Too high output voltage.
variants.c: Flat battery.
variants.d: Overheated alternator.

variants.b: Probably experience failure of the engine ignition system, fuel gauges, aircraft lighting system, and avionics equipment.
variants.c: Probably experience engine failure due to the loss of the engine-driven fuel pump and also experience failure of the radio equipment, lights, and all instruments that require alternating current.

100.title: Can the downdraft air currents occurring as a result of wingtip vortices from a heavier aircraft exceed the climb capability of a light aircraft?

variants.b: Not normally.

101.title: What is the most likely cause of the dangerous turbulence behind heavy aircraft?

variants.b: Propeller blast.
variants.c: Jet blast.

102.title: What precautions are required when stopping a light aircraft behind a heavy aircraft that is stopped on the manoeuvring area?

variants.d: The light aircraft should be no closer than 125 m from rear of large aircraft.

103.title: During a takeoff made behind a departing large jet airplane, the pilot can minimize the hazard of wingtip vortices by :

variants.a: Being airborne prior to reaching the jet's flight path until able to turn clear of its wake.
variants.b: Maintaining extra speed on takeoff and climbout.
variants.c: Extending the takeoff roll and not rotating until well beyond the jet's rotation point.

104.title: When landing behind a large aircraft, the pilot should avoid wake turbulence by staying :

variants.a: Above the large aircraft's final approach flight path and landing beyond the large aircraft's touchdown point.
variants.b: Below the large aircraft's final approach flight path and landing before the large aircraft's touchdown point.
variants.c: Above the large aircraft's final approach flight path and landing before the large aircraft's touchdown point.

105.title: Which procedure should you follow to avoid wake turbulence if a large jet crosses your course from left to right approximately 1 mile ahead and at your altitude?

variants.a: Make sure you are slightly above the path of the jet.
variants.b: Slow your airspeed to VA and maintain altitude and course.
variants.c: Make sure you are slightly below the path of the jet and perpendicular to the course.

106.title: How long will wake turbulence remain after the passage of a large aircraft?

variants.a: Five minutes or more; ATC permits two or three minutes separation.
variants.b: Two minutes.

variants.b: Apply the rudder in direction of rotation, ailerons opposite to direction of rotation, and pull on the stick backward.
variants.c: Apply the rudder opposite to direction of rotation, ailerons to neutral, elevator control backward
